note: His books include Adam Wodeham (Brill, 1978), Covenant and Causality in Medieval Thought (Variorum, 1984), Schools and Scholars in Fourteenth-Century England (Princeton University Press, 1987), Capacity and Volition (Lubrina, 1990), Parisian Scholars in the Early Fourteenth Century (Cambridge University Press, 1999), Rotuli Parisienses, 2 vols (Brill, 2002–04), and Ockham and Ockhamism (Brill, 2008).
title: Charles Homer Haskins and Hilldale Professor Emeritus of History at the University of W isconsin, is a specialist in medieval intellectual and university history. A recipient of fellowships from the National Endowment for the Humanities, the American Council of Learned Societies, the Humboldt Stiftung, the Guggenheim Foundation, and the Institute for Advanced Studies, he is also Fellow of the Medieval Academy of America, American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and Royal Historical Society

container-title: 1991–92, Dr Macy was Heroditus Fellow at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton and during the 2005–06 academic year Senior Luce Fellow at the National Humanities Center. Dr. Macy’s most recent book, The Hidden History of Women’s Ordination
note: was published by Oxford University Press in 2007.
title: SJ Professor of Theology at Santa Clara University, received his bachelor’s and his master’s degrees from Marquette University and his doctoral degree from Cambridge University. He has published ten books and over twenty articles on Christian history and ritual

container-title: Talking Democracy: Historical Approaches to Rhetoric and Democratic Theory (Penn State Press, 2004); and English Political Thought in Early Fourteenth-Century England (Medieval and Renaissance Texts and Studies
note: He has also published approximately one hundred journal articles and book chapters, including contributions to many leading journals in political science, history, philosophy, and medieval studies.
